Question_1.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 using cyclotron-produced gallium-68.
Question_1.Question: What is the main advantage of utilizing liquid-target cyclotron-produced gallium-68 for the synthesis of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46?
Question_1.C: Reduced impurities of Ga-66 and Ga-67
Question_1.Source: The process consistently provides < 2% of Ga-66 and Ga-67 at the 4-h expiry, meeting the Ph. Eur. standards.

Question_2.Context: The paper describes the automated radiosynthesis process for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46.
Question_2.Question: What is the purpose of using an anion exchange cartridge in the synthesis process?
Question_2.A: To trap Ga-66 and Ga-67 impurities
Question_2.B: To elute Ga-68 from the reactor
Question_2.C: To remove zinc and other metals
Question_2.Source: The resulting [68Ga]GaCl3 was transferred to the reactor, where the precursor solution had already been transferred. The resulting reaction solution was heated to 95 °C for 10 min, cooled to room temperature and diluted with 0.9% saline. The resulting solution is passed through a CM cartridge directly to the final vial through a 0.22-micron sterilizing filter.

Question_3.Context: The paper discusses the stability of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 product.
Question_3.Question: What was observed regarding the stability of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 at room temperature for up to 4 hours?
Question_3.Source: Stability studies conducted at room temperature showed no degradation of the product out to 4-h, with consistent radiochemical purities by HPLC shown.

Question_4.Context: The paper details the automated radiosynthesis process for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46.
Question_4.Question: What is the purpose of the CM cartridge in the synthesis process?
Question_4.B: To remove zinc and other metals
Question_4.C: To elute Ga-68 from the reactor
Question_4.Source: Using the optimized conditions established, 43.7 ± 2.5 (n = 3) mCi of [68Ga]FAPI-46 was produced. This is similar to the yields for [68Ga]PSMA-11 previously reported.

Question_5.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 using cyclotron-produced gallium-68.
Question_5.Question: What is the advantage of using the GE FASTlab 2 for the synthesis process?
Question_5.C: Limited positions on the cassette skeleton
Question_5.D: Inability to perform trap and release purification
Question_5.Source: In addition to commercially available cassettes and kits, the FASTlab has a basic cassette skeleton and components available for customized design and radiosynthesis implementation.

Question_6.Context: The paper describes the automated radiosynthesis process for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46.
Question_6.Question: What is the purpose of the ZR resin cartridge in the synthesis process?
Question_6.A: To trap Ga-66 and Ga-67 impurities
Question_6.B: To elute Ga-68 from the reactor
Question_6.C: To remove zinc and other metals
Question_6.Source: The target solution is diluted to ≤ 0.1 M nitric acid by addition of water. The 68Ga is trapped on the first column (ZR Resin) while the zinc is not trapped on the column under these conditions.

Question_7.Context: The paper discusses the stability of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 product.
Question_7.Question: What was observed regarding the pH of the [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 solution during stability testing?
Question_7.Source: The pH of the solution was also consistent demonstrating no radiolytic induced pH change.

Question_8.Context: The paper details the automated radiosynthesis process for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46.
Question_8.Question: What is the purpose of the TK200 resin cartridge in the synthesis process?
Question_8.B: To remove zinc and other metals
Question_8.C: To elute Ga-68 from the reactor
Question_8.Source: Next, the 68Ga is eluted with ~ 1.75 M hydrochloric acid (HCl), passed through the anion exchange cartridge, and trapped in the 3rd column (TK 200 Resin).

Question_9.Context: The paper discusses the synthesis of [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46 using cyclotron-produced gallium-68.
Question_9.Question: What is the advantage of using a liquid-target cyclotron-based route for gallium-68 production?
Question_9.Source: The cyclotron-based route via liquid targets can produce gallium-68 on-demand with workflows similar to fluoride-18 production.

Question_10.Context: The paper describes the automated radiosynthesis process for [68Ga]Ga-FAPI-46.
Question_10.Question: What is the significance of the Ga-66 and Ga-67 impurities level in the final product?
Question_10.Source: Furthermore, the process consistently provides < 2% of Ga-66 and Ga-67 at the 4-h expiry, meeting the Ph. Eur. standards.
